item.title: A Re-Evaluation of the Approaches to Learning Questionnaire
Disciplinary Differences in Blended Learning Design: A Network Analytic Study
item.description: Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

item.title: Disciplinary Differences in Blended Learning Design: A Network Analytic Study
item.description: Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

item.title: Approaches to Learning: A Re-Evaluation
item.description:
Introduction

For my first blog post, I thought I would provide an outline of a work in progress paper that seeks to re-evaluate the work of Biggs, Kember, and Leung (2001). This previous work of Biggs, Kember, and Leung (2001) led to the creation of the Revised Two-Factor Study Process Questionnaire (R-SPQ-2F) that has been extensively used, predominately as a means of profiling students (i.e., categorising students as Deep or Surface learners). Using data acquired from an institutional survey containing the 20-item R-SPQ-2F (n = 1158), two proposed models of Biggs, Kember, and Leung (2001) were evaluated – a general summary is given below.

Proposed Models

The first model is presented in Figure 1 and shows four factors (Deep Motive, Deep Strategy, Surface Strategy, and Surface Motive), each of which is measured by five items. The following correlations are specified:

  • Between Deep Motive and Deep Strategy
  • Between Deep Motive and Surface Motive
  • Between Surfrace Strategy and Surface Motive

No correlations were specified between the errors of any of the 20 items

The original work of Biggs, Kember, and Leung (2001) reported a Comparative Fit Index (CFI) of .904 and Root Mean Square Residual (RMSR) of .058 for this first model. The latter does not fully meet the repeatedly touted rule of thumbs resulting from the simulation work of Hu and Bentler (1999) (i.e., CFI = .95, SRMR = .08).

Figure 1: Proposed Item Level Model of the R-SPQ-2F

Model two is presented in Figure 2 and is composed of two higher-order factors, each measured by two factors. The two lower-order factors were created through item parcelling and resulted in a marked improvement in model fit (CFI = .992, SRMR = .015; Biggs, Kember, and Leung 2001).

Figure 2: Higher Order Factor Model of the R-SPQ-2F

Obtaining a “better fitting” model through the process of item-parcelling is a contentious issue, particularly as it masks areas of ill-fit. Marsh et al. (2013) have previously stated that only when the conservative assumptions of Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) are supported (i.e., no cross-loadings or correlated errors) then item-parcelling may be appropriate as the factors are unidimensional.

Re-Analysis

Using the aforementioned collected data, I will demonstrate that both models (Figure 1 and 2) are not supported.

Model One

To explore Model One (Figure 1), the data will be analysed using CFA, following the specifications of Biggs, Kember, and Leung (2001).

biggs_model_one <- '

  deep_strategy =~ Q1 + Q5 + Q9 + Q13 + Q17
  
  deep_motive =~ Q2 + Q6 + Q10 + Q14 + Q18
  
  surface_strategy =~ Q3 + Q7 + Q11 + Q15 + Q19
  
  surface_motive =~ Q4 + Q8 + Q12 + Q16 + Q20
  
  deep_strategy ~~ deep_motive
  deep_strategy ~~ 0*surface_strategy
  deep_strategy ~~ 0*surface_motive
  
  deep_motive ~~ surface_motive
  deep_motive ~~ 0*surface_strategy
  
  surface_strategy ~~ surface_motive
'

biggs_model_one_cfa <- 
  cfa(model = biggs_model_one,
      data = biggsData,
      ordered = c("Q1", "Q2", "Q3", "Q4", "Q5",
                  "Q6", "Q7", "Q8", "Q9", "Q10",
                  "Q11", "Q12", "Q13", "Q14", "Q15",
                  "Q16", "Q17", "Q18", "Q19", "Q20"),
      estimator = "WLSMV")
## Warning in lav_object_post_check(object): lavaan WARNING: covariance matrix of latent variables
##                 is not positive definite;
##                 use lavInspect(fit, "cov.lv") to investigate.
summary(biggs_model_one_cfa)
## lavaan 0.6-6 ended normally after 39 iterations
## 
##   Estimator                                       DWLS
##   Optimization method                           NLMINB
##   Number of free parameters                        103
##                                                       
##   Number of observations                          1158
##                                                       
## Model Test User Model:
##                                               Standard      Robust
##   Test Statistic                              2019.882    1190.331
##   Degrees of freedom                               167         167
##   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000       0.000
##   Scaling correction factor                                  1.849
##   Shift parameter                                           97.843
##        simple second-order correction                             
## 
## Parameter Estimates:
## 
##   Standard errors                           Robust.sem
##   Information                                 Expected
##   Information saturated (h1) model        Unstructured
## 
## Latent Variables:
##                       Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
##   deep_strategy =~                                       
##     Q1                   1.000                           
##     Q5                   0.936    0.036   25.663    0.000
##     Q9                   1.096    0.039   28.389    0.000
##     Q13                  1.157    0.037   31.029    0.000
##     Q17                  0.888    0.039   22.626    0.000
##   deep_motive =~                                         
##     Q2                   1.000                           
##     Q6                   1.236    0.041   29.972    0.000

##     Q14                  1.176    0.042   27.763    0.000

##   surface_strategy =~                                    
##     Q3                   1.000                           
##     Q7                   1.048    0.049   21.368    0.000

##     Q15                  1.113    0.049   22.710    0.000
##     Q19                  1.191    0.052   23.053    0.000
##   surface_motive =~                                      
##     Q4                   1.000                           
##     Q8                   1.066    0.062   17.139    0.000
##     Q12                  1.307    0.063   20.713    0.000
##     Q16                  1.289    0.067   19.263    0.000
##     Q20                  1.056    0.064   16.479    0.000
## 
## Covariances:
##                       Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
##   deep_strategy ~~                                       
##     deep_motive          0.410    0.020   20.447    0.000

##     surface_motive       0.000                           
##   deep_motive ~~                                         
##     surface_motive      -0.008    0.012   -0.672    0.502
##     surface_strtgy       0.000                           
##   surface_strategy ~~

##     Q15|t1           -0.236    0.037   -6.339    0.000

##     Q19|t3            0.644    0.040   16.187    0.000
##     Q19|t4            1.342    0.052   25.885    0.000
##     Q4|t1            -1.210    0.049  -24.929    0.000
##     Q4|t2            -0.417    0.038  -10.952    0.000
##     Q4|t3             0.258    0.037    6.925    0.000
##     Q4|t4             1.342    0.052   25.885    0.000
##     Q8|t1            -0.816    0.042  -19.582    0.000
##     Q8|t2             0.015    0.037    0.411    0.681
##     Q8|t3             0.687    0.040   17.090    0.000
##     Q8|t4             1.509    0.057   26.481    0.000
##     Q12|t1           -1.054    0.045  -23.246    0.000
##     Q12|t2           -0.098    0.037   -2.643    0.008
##     Q12|t3            0.679    0.040   16.921    0.000
##     Q12|t4            1.687    0.064   26.389    0.000
##     Q16|t1           -1.093    0.046  -23.716    0.000
##     Q16|t2           -0.312    0.038   -8.329    0.000
##     Q16|t3            0.303    0.037    8.095    0.000
##     Q16|t4            1.035    0.045   23.005    0.000
##     Q20|t1           -0.665    0.040  -16.640    0.000
##     Q20|t2            0.056    0.037    1.527    0.127
##     Q20|t3            0.706    0.040   17.483    0.000
##     Q20|t4            1.483    0.056   26.432    0.000
## 
## Variances:
##                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
##    .Q1                0.570                           
##    .Q5                0.623                           
##    .Q9                0.483                           
##    .Q13               0.424                           
##    .Q17               0.660                           
##    .Q2                0.615                           
##    .Q6                0.412                           
##    .Q10               0.587                           
##    .Q14               0.468                           
##    .Q18               0.734

##    .Q11               0.567                           
##    .Q15               0.555                           
##    .Q19               0.490                           
##    .Q4                0.750                           
##    .Q8                0.716                           
##    .Q12               0.573                           
##    .Q16               0.584                           
##    .Q20               0.721                           
##     deep_strategy     0.430    0.025   16.966    0.000
##     deep_motive       0.385    0.025   15.564    0.000
##     surface_strtgy    0.360    0.028   12.810    0.000
##     surface_motive    0.250    0.023   10.668    0.000
## 
## Scales y*:
##                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
##     Q1                1.000                           
##     Q5                1.000                           
##     Q9                1.000                           
##     Q13               1.000                           
##     Q17               1.000                           
##     Q2                1.000                           
##     Q6                1.000                           
##     Q10               1.000                           
##     Q14               1.000                           
##     Q18               1.000                           
##     Q3                1.000                           
##     Q7                1.000                           
##     Q11               1.000                           
##     Q15               1.000                           
##     Q19               1.000                           
##     Q4                1.000                           
##     Q8                1.000                           
##     Q12               1.000                           
##     Q16               1.000                           
##     Q20               1.000
lavInspect(biggs_model_one_cfa, "cov.lv")
##                  dp_str dp_mtv srfc_s srfc_m
## deep_strategy     0.430                     
## deep_motive       0.410  0.385              
## surface_strategy  0.000  0.000  0.360       
## surface_motive    0.000 -0.008  0.310  0.250

Model One was found to not be positive definite and can be attributed to a model implied covariance value of -.008 between the Deep Motive and Surface Motive factors. The model can viewed as being misspecified and is therefore rejected.

Model Two

To evaluate whether the item-parcelling approach is appropriate when using the R-SPQ-2F, the unidimensionality of the four factors will be explored using Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA).

biggs_model_two_efa <-
  fa(r = biggsData,
     nfactors = 4,
     rotate = "varimax",
     fm = "wls")

print.psych(biggs_model_two_efa,
            digits = 2,
            cut = .2)
## Factor Analysis using method =  wls
## Call: fa(r = biggsData, nfactors = 4, rotate = "varimax", fm = "wls")
## Standardized loadings (pattern matrix) based upon correlation matrix
##      WLS1  WLS2  WLS4  WLS3   h2   u2 com
## Q1   0.63             -0.22 0.46 0.54 1.3
## Q2   0.59             -0.22 0.40 0.60 1.3
## Q3         0.56             0.35 0.65 1.2
## Q4         0.52       -0.23 0.33 0.67 1.4
## Q5   0.59                   0.36 0.64 1.0
## Q6   0.72                   0.55 0.45 1.1
## Q7         0.59        0.24 0.44 0.56 1.5
## Q8         0.35  0.67       0.59 0.41 1.6
## Q9   0.68                   0.47 0.53 1.0
## Q10  0.61        0.22       0.44 0.56 1.3
## Q11        0.49  0.50       0.50 0.50 2.2
## Q12        0.61             0.41 0.59 1.2
## Q13  0.73                   0.54 0.46 1.1
## Q14  0.68              0.35 0.58 0.42 1.5
## Q15        0.59        0.24 0.43 0.57 1.5
## Q16        0.61       -0.21 0.42 0.58 1.2
## Q17  0.53              0.26 0.37 0.63 1.6
## Q18  0.47                   0.28 0.72 1.6
## Q19        0.68             0.49 0.51 1.1
## Q20        0.45  0.24       0.28 0.72 1.7
## 
##                       WLS1 WLS2 WLS4 WLS3
## SS loadings           4.02 3.09 0.90 0.68
## Proportion Var        0.20 0.15 0.05 0.03
## Cumulative Var        0.20 0.36 0.40 0.43
## Proportion Explained  0.46 0.36 0.10 0.08
## Cumulative Proportion 0.46 0.82 0.92 1.00
## 
## Mean item complexity =  1.4
## Test of the hypothesis that 4 factors are sufficient.
## 
## The degrees of freedom for the null model are  190  and the objective function was  6.41 with Chi Square of  7364.85
## The degrees of freedom for the model are 116  and the objective function was  0.43 
## 
## The root mean square of the residuals (RMSR) is  0.03 
## The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.04 
## 
## The harmonic number of observations is  1158 with the empirical chi square  344.76  with prob <  1.5e-24 
## The total number of observations was  1158  with Likelihood Chi Square =  494.66  with prob <  3.2e-48 
## 
## Tucker Lewis Index of factoring reliability =  0.913
## RMSEA index =  0.053  and the 90 % confidence intervals are  0.048 0.058
## BIC =  -323.66
## Fit based upon off diagonal values = 0.99
## Measures of factor score adequacy             
##                                                   WLS1 WLS2 WLS4 WLS3
## Correlation of (regression) scores with factors   0.94 0.90 0.77 0.74
## Multiple R square of scores with factors          0.88 0.81 0.59 0.55
## Minimum correlation of possible factor scores     0.76 0.62 0.17 0.09

Three points can be made on the basis of the EFA results:

  • A four factor solution does not seem to be supported – the third factor has seven absolute values below .30
  • Unidimensionality of the purported four factors is not supported – some items have loadings on non-target factors that are not of a nominal value (e.g., item 11)
  • There may be a case for a two factor model (Deep and Surface Approaches) without the need to break these up into Strategy and Motive factors.

Conclusion

The results do not provide support for the original work of Biggs, Kember, and Leung (2001):

  • Model One (Figure 1) results in an inadmissible solution
  • Model Two (Figure 2) does not support the criteria of unidimensionality (Marsh et al. 2013) that would make item-parcelling an admissible approach

The work reiterates the importance of measurement and how this could potentially impact further research. And while the original models were not supported, there may be utility in exploring alternative factor models or approaches altogether (e.g., the characterisation of trace data).

References

Biggs, John, David Kember, and Doris Y. P. Leung. 2001. “The Revised Two-Factor Study Process Questionnaire: R-Spq-2F.” British Journal of Educational Psychology 71 (1): 133–49. https://doi.org/10.1348/000709901158433.

Hu, Li‐tze, and Peter M. Bentler. 1999. “Cutoff Criteria for Fit Indexes in Covariance Structure Analysis: Conventional Criteria Versus New Alternatives.” Structural Equation Modeling: A Multidisciplinary Journal 6 (1): 1–55. https://doi.org/10.1080/10705519909540118.

Marsh, Herbert W., Oliver Lüdtke, Benjamin Nagengast, Alexandre J. S. Morin, and Matthias von Davier. 2013. “Why Item Parcels Are (Almost) Never Appropriate: Two Wrongs Do Not Make a Right—Camouflaging Misspecification with Item Parcels in CFA Models.” Psychological Methods 18 (3): 257–84. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0032773.

item.title: Assessing the validity of a learning analytics expectation instrument: A multinational study
Exploring Student Information Problem Solving Behaviour Using Fine-Grained Concept Map and Search Tool Data
The Student Expectations of Learning Analytics Questionnaire
Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let's make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation
